conversation.content:
[confused] Wait, what? They've been—for months? Um, I just found out from Rachel that basically everyone in ortho has been, you know, questioning whether I should even be operating. [pause] Like, actually discussing my cases behind my back. [frustrated] The thing is, I've been working alongside these people for what—six years? And they're just, er, sitting around analyzing every single decision I make? [bitter] Oh sure, they smile at me in the OR, ask about my weekend, but apparently, [shaky voice] the whole time they've been keeping some kind of mental scorecard. 

[sigh] I mean, okay, so maybe I had that one complication with the hip replacement, but honestly, who hasn't? [angry] It's just—God, Marcus was literally asking me for advice on ACL repairs last week! [very quietly] And now I'm wondering if he was, like, testing me or something. 

[hurt] The thing that really gets me is, um, nobody said anything to my face. Not one person. [speeding up] They could've pulled me aside, offered help, I don't know, literally anything except this—this backstabbing nonsense. [pause] 

[exhausted] Anyway, I guess now I know why I wasn't invited to that conference dinner. [trailing off] Thought it was just an oversight, but...

subject: Finding out your orthopedic surgeon colleagues have been questioning your competence behind your back for months
